entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
In a recent exchange on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List, an innovative approach to integrating quantum-resistant mechanisms into the Bitcoin protocol was discussed. The conversation revolved around the use of ECDSA signatures, which are fundamental to Bitcoin's security. It was noted that while the public key used in transactions is static and unchangeable if already present in the output script, the R-value, which is also a critical component of the signature, can be selected freely by the signer. This flexibility with the R-value presents a unique opportunity for Bitcoin to evolve towards quantum resistance.
The proposal suggests that users could leverage the R-value within ECDSA signatures to commit to quantum-resistant data. By hashing quantum data and forming a commitment in the R-value, the network could facilitate a transitional phase where both traditional ECDSA and new quantum-resistant data coexist. Initially, this quantum commitment would be optional, allowing transactions to remain compatible with both older nodes that only recognize ECDSA signatures and newer, quantum-aware nodes. These quantum nodes would have the capability to interpret the additional data committed to the R-values, effectively bridging the gap between current cryptographic standards and future quantum-resistant solutions.
As the network progresses, the integration of quantum-resistant signatures would become mandatory. In this phase, every operation verifying a signature (OP_CHECKSIG) would require the R-value of ECDSA signatures to encapsulate a valid quantum commitment. Importantly, this method sidesteps potential scalability issues related to block size limits by instead tying the feasibility of quantum commitments to a combination of the existing signature operations limit and a new, adjustable quantum commitment size limit. This flexible approach allows for the accommodation of various quantum-resistant schemes without necessitating a direct increase in block size, thereby offering a scalable solution to quantum threats against Bitcoin's cryptographic infrastructure.
